fields.root_distribution_over_depth: LIN partitioning from emergence to maturity
fields.water_dynamics: C(15), Water table dyn. (runoff, ET, percolation, sub surface flow

fields.spatial_scale_of_calibration_validation: Calibration at gridcell level (0.5º resolution)/validation at national level

fields.calibrated_values: Specific for each crop and region
fields.criteria_for_evaluation: Iterative parameter fitting (management factor) to perfect fit

fields.crops: whe(w,s), rice, mai, mill, sub, cass, fpea, soy, sunfl, rapes, gnut, suc
fields.planting_date_decision: S (Waha et al. 2012) during spinup and F to those dates after spinup in DEFAULT sims, F in HARMNON sims
fields.planting_density: S (Waha et al. 2012) during spinup and F to those dates after spinup in DEFAULT sims, F in HARMNON sims
fields.calibrated_values: Specific for each crop and country

fields.impact_types_other: reduced productivity in agriculture, energy for irrigation

fields.model_type: Optimisation (least-cost) integrated energy system expansion model (average and plant level)
fields.output_energy_supply: Hydropower potential, wind potential, water impacts on thermal efficiency, land impacts on bioenergy crops
fields.output_water_scarcity: Impact of thermal power generation with CCS on water availability

fields.model_type: Simulation model for individual power plants, combined with a dispatch model for European electricity production
fields.output_economics: Electricity prices, imports/exports, producer and consumer rents

fields.model_type: Thermoelectric and hydropower production models coupled to hydrological and water temperature models
fields.output_energy_supply: Hydropower and thermoelectric power production potential

fields.output_energy_demand: HDD/CDD, demand for heating and air conditioning, energy demand for buildings
fields.output_energy_supply: Hydropower potential and associated electricity generation

fields.model_type: Cost optimisation model of the energy system
fields.output_economics: Energy system costs, carbon p rices, fossil fuel prices, CC damage costs

fields.model_type: Spatialization of renewable scenarios for wind and solar PV locations, physical models of the electricity production for wind and solar pv from climate variables
fields.output_energy_supply: Electrical power for wind and solar

fields.soil_layers: Five hydrologically active soil layers, coupled to carbon and thermal balance
fields.water_sectors: two versions available: one with irrigation only, the other including additional water uses; existing runs on server have to be replaced because of setup errors; upload of new data pending on naming decision
fields.routing: Continuity equation derived from linear reservoir model, routing data according to DDM30
fields.land_use: Different partitioning of rainfall depending on vegetation status of managed areas (cropland and pastures)
fields.dams_reservoirs: Reservoirs collect water from the river system for distribution to connected irrigation areas. Evaporation from reservoir surface is calculated. Minumum release for environmental flow.
fields.vegetation_representation: Dynamic simulation of growth and productivity (with prescribed spatial distribution of crops and pasture); dynamic vegetation composition on PNV areas

fields.routing:
Unit hydrograph approach

see Lohmann, et. al. "A large‐scale horizontal routing model to be coupled to land surface parametrization schemes." Tellus A 48.5 (1996): 708-721.
fields.land_use: Irrigation area. Irrigation starts as additional precipitation during the growing season when soil moisture drops below the wilting point and stops until field capacity is reached.
fields.dams_reservoirs: Dam opeartion is optimized based on reservoir functions such as flood control, irrigation, hydropower generation, and water supply
fields.calibration_catchments: Observed flow was inversely routed to 1-deg resoulution grid cell first for 44 basins. Calibration was done for every 1-deg grid cell seperately

fields.soil_layers: 15 soil layers (soil moisture is simulated for the first 10 layers)

fields.land_use: Varied areas for irrigation and rainfed cropland were used for varsoc runs
fields.dams_reservoirs: Include a reservoir regulation scheme in the routing model, use GRanD dataset, the number of dams and reservoirs varies for the varsoc runs.

fields.soil_layers: 1-layerSoil information was not incorporated, but runoff properties vary with climate zones (see Appendix C of Hanasaki et al. (2008a) for details)
fields.water_use: irrigation (computed internally), domestic water (prescribed), industrial water (prescribed)
fields.water_sectors:
[pressoc/varsoc runs submitted before Dec.2015]

irrigation (computed internally), domestic water (prescribed), industrial water (prescribed)
fields.land_use: For varsoc run, time-varying cultivars and irrigated/rain-fed cultivation were included for croplands.
fields.dams_reservoirs: Dams and reservoirs were implemented based on the protocol (GranD). For varsoc run, the construction year of each dam/reservoir was taken into accounted.
fields.vegetation_representation:
Each land cell is subdivided into four land use (double-cropping irrigated cropland, single-cropping irrigated cropland, rain-fed cropland and natural use). Crop growth depends on given meteorological conditions.

 [For nosoc run]
Natural use: Globally uniform. No-specific land type is assigned, as known as Manabe's bucket. 

[For pressoc run]
Croplands: Fixed cultivars according to HYDE/MIRCA at 2000 with fixed planting dates. Geographical distribution of irrigated/rainfed cropland was based on HYDE/MIRCA at 2000. We assumed the geographical distribution of double-cropping cultivation was based on Siebert et al. (2005).
Natural use: Globally uniform. No-specific land type is assigned, as known as Manabe's bucket. 

[For varsoc run]
Croplands: Changing cultivars according to HYDE/MIRCA with fixed planting dates. Geographical distribution of irrigated/rainfed cropland was based on HYDE/MIRCA at a given year. We assumed the geographical distribution of double-cropping cultivation was fixed throughout the period and based on Siebert et al. (2005).
Natural use: Globally uniform. No-specific land type is assigned, as known as Manabe's bucket.

fields.technological_progress: Industrial and domestic water demand which relfect GDP growth are one of input of the model
fields.water_sectors: Under process of simulation: Irrigation (simulated), doemstic (prescribed), industrial (precribed)
fields.routing: TRIP (Oki et al. 1999), constant flow velocity (5m/s), DDM30 river routine, GRanD resevoirs (pressoc and varsoc)
fields.dams_reservoirs: Use GranDR resevoir data. Reservoir operation is Monthly base operation and dynamically linked with routing. For varsoc run, the construction year of each dam/reservoir was taken into accounted.
fields.vegetation_representation: Monthly LAI, and fixed vegetation characteristics for 12 types of natural land cover

Dynamic simulation of growth and productivity (with prescribed spatial distribution of crops and pasture), annual natural vegetation fraction (PFTs) is forced based on harmonized GLC2000 for year 2000 and LUH dataset (Hurtt et al., 2011) for land cover change.
fields.methods_evapotranspiration:
"Penman-Monteith,  Milly’s correction
for soil moisture stress is applied."
fields.methods_snowmelt: Energy balance at the snow surface

fields.technological_progress: GDP changes and technological development have been integrated in the caluclation of water use (industrial and domestic sector)
fields.routing: Travel time routing (charateristic distance) linked with dynamic reservoir operation (pressoc, varsoc)
fields.land_use: Irrigation, rainfed, natural vegetation (tall and short classes)
fields.dams_reservoirs: Reservoir operation is dynamically linked with routing
fields.vegetation_representation: Annually prescribed (daily charateristics) consistently with land cover change

fields.calibration_years: Calibration against multiple hydrological reference data available in different years, overall spanning a period from 1984-2012
fields.methods_evapotranspiration: net radiation used instead of potential evapotranspiration

fields.technological_progress: Via water use models (details in Flörke, M., Kynast, E., Bärlund, I., Eisner, S., Wimmer, F., and  Alcamo, J.: Domestic and industrial water uses of the past 60 years as a mirror of socio-economic development: A global simulation study, Global Environ. Change, 23, 144–156, doi: 10.1016/j.gloenvcha.2012.10.018, 2013.)
fields.water_use: domestic, manufacturing, cooling of thermal power plant, livestock and irrigation sectors
fields.routing: Linear reservoir, flow velocity based on Manning-Strickler
fields.land_use: Only static land use map is used (IGBP classification based on MODIS data from the year 2004). Irrigation area is varying from year to year.
fields.dams_reservoirs: Water balance of reservoirs and big lakes are calculated in the grid cell that represents the outlet; reservoirs are in operation in its start year; reservoir algorithm after Hanasaki et al. (2006), described in Döll & Fiedler (2008), HESS
fields.calibration_years: Years where GRDC data are available for the specific basin (from 1920-2009) but max. 30 years with a preferred time span from 1971-2000 for WFD, PGFv2, GSWP3; and 1979-2008 for WFD_WFDEI
fields.calibration_dataset: We calibrated WaterGAP for each climate dataset using all water sectors. Additionally, we have homogenized temperature and radiation from WFD for WFDEI to overcome the offset between both forcings (method described in Müller Schmied et al 2016 (HESS, doi:10.5194/hess-2015-527) and calibrated with that; but used the not homogenized forcing WFD_WFDEI from ISI-MIP to run the simulation
fields.calibration_catchments: All: 1319 basins, WFD (due to time limitation: 1312 basins), covering ~54% of global land surface (except Antarctica and Greenland)
fields.vegetation_representation: Temperature and precipitation based LAI-model, fixed rooting depth
fields.methods_evapotranspiration: Priestley Taylor with two alpha factors depending on the aridity of the grid cell

fields.soil_layers: For water: the uppermost drying layer, rooting layer and a layer between the lower boundary of rooting zone and the upper impermeable layer. For energy: freezing and thawing zones.
fields.routing: Kinematic wave equation for water transfer within a grid cell and a linear routing scheme by Oki et al. 1999 for water transfer in a river channel.
fields.calibration_years: Varied depending on the data availability in different basins

fields.soil_layers: Up to 10 soil layers, 11 soil parameters

fields.routing: Linear reservoir, flow velocity based on Manning-Strickler
fields.vegetation_representation: Temperature- dependent  LAI, fixed rooting depth

fields.soil_layers: N soil layers (here two soil layers were used)
fields.land_use: Canopy interception, soil moisture dynamics and runoff generation, as well as runoff routing processes
fields.calibration_years: Varied depending on the data availability in different basins
fields.methods_evapotranspiration: Hargreaves and Samani method + aspect correction

fields.calibration_years: Varied depending on the data availability
fields.vegetation_representation: mean areal crop coeffcient timeseries per subbasin and gras-reference evapotranspiration

fields.routing: Quick and slow flows tanks and  linear reservoirs
Trough a series of linear and non-linear reserviors
fields.calibration_years: Varied depending on the data availability in different basins

fields.soil_layers: Up to 10 soil layers, 11 soil parameters
Three soil layers and up to 10 soil types with individual parameters
fields.routing: Reservoir cascade from ground and surface discharge
fields.methods_snowmelt: Degree-day method or simplified energy approaches

fields.nitrogen_limitation: no, but downregulation of Vcmax under high CO2 is implemented
fields.light_interception: big leaf approach with separation of sun and shaded leaves
fields.mortality_other: cold temperatures, light competition between storeys

fields.output_per_pft: Already averaged over the whole grid
fields.water_stress: Influence on photosynthesis, carbon allocation, evapotranspiration, and soil biogeochemical processes
fields.evapotranspiration_approach: Stomatal resistance, linked to photosynthesis; bulk transfer formula
fields.mortality_stochastic_random_disturbance: yes (random cold temperature trigger leaf falling)
fields.nbp_harvest: Harvest from crops and forest. 1) total aboveground crop C * harvest index (fraction of edible parts) * fraction left after loss due to weeds, failed crop etc.; harvested crop C is transported horizontally (see Zeng et a. 2014), remaining biomass sent to metabolic ltter pool; 2) sustainable wood harvest
fields.list_of_pfts: Broad-leaved tree; needleleaf tree; (Whether diciduous or evergreen is dynamically determined); cold grass; warm grass; generic crop
fields.pfts_comments: provided by Fang Zhao (with input from Ning Zeng) 2/16

fields.output: DLEM output is based on per grid-cell area. when calculating global or regional total, one should multiple by grid area.
fields.output_per_pft: DLEM output is based on grid-cell area. We did not provide output for each PFT type.
fields.phenology: Fixed annual phenology based on satellite observation
fields.water_stress: Influence on photosynthesis, carbon allocation, evapotranspiration, and soil biogeochemical processes
fields.evapotranspiration_approach: Penman-Monteith equation, with the consideration of soil moisture availability
fields.root_distribution: PFT-specific root distribution by following Zeng 2001, "Global vegetation root distribution for land modeling"
fields.closed_energy_balance: DLEM does not calculate energy balance at land surface
fields.latent_heat: yes, latent heat is based on ET (Penman-monteith equation)
fields.mortality_age: yes, DLEM set a maximum age (AGEmax) for each PFT type. In each year, DLEM assume 1/AGEmax of this vegetation die due to aging effect.
fields.mortality_remarks: DLEM has a process-based fire module to estimate burned area, fire emissions, and fire mortality. However, we did not switch on Fire module in the ISIMIP simulation.
fields.nbp_landuse_change: yes, DLEM assumes that part of biomass transferred to litter and woody debris pool; part of them transferred to product pools; and the left directly released to the atmosphere due to burning.
fields.nbp_harvest: 1. harvested crop biomass tranferred to product pool. Crop residue and straw biomass tranferred to litter pool. 2. no forest harvest. 3. no grassalnd harvest.
fields.list_of_pfts: Tundra (T); Boreal Broadleaf Deciduous Forest (BBDF); Boreal Needleleaf Evergreen Forest (BNEF); Boreal Needleleaf Deciduous Forest (BNDF); Temperate Broadleaf Deciduous Forest (TBDF); Temperate Broadleaf Evergreen Forest (TBEF); Temperate Needleleaf Evergreen Forest (TNEF); Temperate Needleleaf Deciduous Forest (TNDF); Tropical Broadleaf Deciduous Forest (TrBDF); Tropical Broadleaf Evergreen Forest (TrBEF); Deciduous Shrub (Dshrub); Evergreen Shrub (Eshrub); C3 grassland (C3G); C4 grassland (C4G); Cropland
fields.pfts_comments: Cropland (14 types including: Barly, Cassava, Cotton, Corn, Millet, Potato, Rapeseed, Rice, Sorghum, Soybeen, Sugarcane, Sunflower, Wheat, Oat), provided by Hanqin Tian - 30-10-2015

fields.output: per grid cell (land only), thus when calculating global or regional total, please multiply by grid-cell area of each grid
fields.output_per_pft: output per PFT per unit area of that PFT in the grid cell. Grid box average requires weighting by the fractional coverage of each PFT in  the gridbox.
fields.considerations:
13 PFTs including bare soil, lakes,Urban area, ice etc.
For monthly value, please multiply PFT specific value by PFT fraction of each PFTs
fields.dynamic_vegetation: Competition between natural PFTs is based on a tree-shrub-grass dominance hierarchy,
fields.light_utilization: follow the JULES canopy radiation model 5 that uses a two-stream approximation of radiation interception in a 10-layer canopy. There two leaves in each canopy layer (sunlit and shaded)
fields.water_stress: Water stress affects the photosynthesis and leaf maintenance respiration
fields.heat_stress: aggregated degree-day sum that affect phenology
fields.list_of_pfts: tropical broadleaf evergreen trees (BDT); temperatre broadleaf evergreen trees (BET_te);deciduous broadleaf trees (BET_tr); evergreen needleleaf trees (NET ); deciduous needleleaf trees (NDT); c3 grass (C3); c4 grass (C4);evergreen shrub (ESh); deciduous shrub (DSh) ; Urban (Urb),Inland Water (Water); Bare soil (Soil); ice (ice)

fields.output_per_pft: grid-cell totals; pft fraction not normalized, sum can be larger than 1
fields.phenology: differentiation between evergreen (constant leaf coverage over the year), raingreen (maximum leaf coverage until water stress threshold) and summergreen (budburst and senescence controlled by base temperature, leaf cover increases with accumulated heat sum) trees
fields.water_stress: influence on photosynthesis, allocation (roots/leaf), triggers leaf abscission in raingreen trees
fields.nbp_fire: 1) yes 2) burnt area fraction calculated at the end of each year, biomass C and above-ground litter C released to atmosphere
fields.nbp_landuse_change: all biomass transferred to litter pools on land use change; no slash-and-burn or other treatment

fields.output_per_pft: grid-cell totals provided for all variables that are also provided differentiated by PFT; NPP and GPP: for PNV types normalized to area covered by all natural vegetation, for crops normalized to fraction covered by crop
fields.considerations: do not analyse GPP/NPP of "others rainfed/irrigated"
fields.phenology: differentiation between evergreen (constant leaf coverage over the year), raingreen (maximum leaf coverage until water stress threshold) and summergreen (budburst and senescence controlled by base temperature, leaf cover increases with accumulated heat sum) trees
fields.water_stress: influence on photosynthesis, allocation (roots/leaf), triggers leaf abscission in raingreen trees
fields.heat_stress: aggregated degree-day sum over PFT-specific temperature base, only on boreal trees
fields.sensible_heat: yes, but only for soil temperature
fields.mortality_fire: 1) annual burnt grid fraction based on length of fire season, mortality based on PFT-specific fire resistence; 2) daily fire probability depends on litter moisture
fields.mortality_remarks: growth efficiency, climatic stress (heat threshold, long-term mean outside bioclimatic limits), plant density (FPC>1)
fields.nbp_fire: 1) yes 2) burnt area fraction calculated at the end of each year, biomass C and above-ground litter C released to atmosphere
fields.nbp_landuse_change: all biomass transferred to litter pools on land use change; no slash-and-burn or other treatment
fields.nbp_harvest: 1) C from storage organ added to annual harvest flux, remaining biomass sent to litter; 2) no forest harvest; 3) 50% of leaf biomass harvested (added to harvest flux) whenever biomass increment exceeds 100g/m2
fields.nbp_comments: note that monthly NBP is derived by substracting annual fire and annual harvest fluxes as well as monthly RH from monthly NPP, i.e. annual values more reliable than seasonal cycle
fields.list_of_pfts: tropical broad-leaved evergreen tree; tropical broad-leaved raingreen tree; temperate needle-leaved evergreen tree; temperate broad-leaved evergreen tree; temperate broad-leaved summergreen tree; boreal needle-leaved evergreen tree; boreal broad-leaved summergreen tree; temperate herbaceous (C3 perennial grass); tropical herbaceous (C4 perennial grass); temperate cereals (whe); rice (ric), maize (mai), tropical cereals (mil); pulses (pea), temperate roots (sgb), tropical roots (cas); oil crops sunflower (sun); oil crops soybean (soy); oil crops groundnut (nut); oil crops rapeseed (rap); sugarcane (sug)
fields.pfts_comments: Crop groups: temperate cereals: wheat, barley, rye, oat; tropical cereals: millet, sorghum; pulses: lentils, temperate roots: sugar beet, tropical roots: cassava; results for managed grasslands abbreviated with "mgr", contain a mixture of C3 and C4 grass based on bioclimatic limits; all remaining crop areas (others) simulated as managed grasslands - do not analyse, especially others_irrigated

fields.output: per land area, thus when calculating global or regional total, please multiply by land area of each grid
fields.output_per_pft: grid-cell totals provided for all variables that are also provided differentiated by PFT but for annual time step. For monthly value, please multiply PFT specific value by PFT fraction of each PFTs (16 PFTs including bare soil but not non-land type water, ice etc.)
fields.heat_stress: aggregated degree-day sum that affect phenology
fields.evapotranspiration_approach:
"Penman-Monteith,  Milly’s correction
for soil moisture stress is applied."
fields.mortality_fire: for forests no mortality and fire
fields.mortality_remarks: for different pools and for grasslands still climate dependence leading to mortality
fields.nbp_landuse_change: yes, all deforestrated biomass transferred to litter pools on land use change
fields.nbp_harvest: 1) C from storage organ added to annual harvest flux, remaining biomass sent to litter; 2) no forest harvest
fields.list_of_pfts: Bare soil (bare); tropical broad-leaved evergreen (trbrev); tropical broad-leaved raingreen (trbrrg); temperate needleleaf evergreen (tendev); temperate broad-leaved evergreen (tebrev); temperate broad-leaved summergreen (tebrsu); boreal needleleaf evergreen (bondev); boreal broad-leaved summergreen (bobrsu); boreal needleleaf summergreen (bondsu); C3 grass (c3gra); C4 grass (c4gra); C3 winter crop (c3win); C3 summer crop (c3sum); C3 rapeseed (c3ras); C4 maize (c4mai); C4 other crops (c4oth)

fields.output: per forest stand/ per simulated forest unit
fields.dynamic_vegetation:
yes:
Forest dynamics are described by forest growth, regeneration/planting, management.
fields.nitrogen_limitation:
yes
Different approaches are used to estimate the nitrogen depending reduction of NPP. Nitrogen supply  is calculated by a soil model (water, temperature, C/N module) from the soil conditions, the litter input and nitrogen uptake and leaching.
fields.co2_effects: The annual course of net photosynthesis is simulated with a mechanistic formulation of net photosynthesis as a function of environmental influences (temperature, water and nitrogen availability, radiation, and CO2) where the physiological capacity (maximal carboxylation rate) is calculated based on optimisation theory (modified after Haxeltine and Prentice, 1996) plus calculation of total tree respiration following the concept of constant annual respiration fraction as proposed by Landsberg and Waring (1997).
fields.light_interception:
yes:
The share of any tree cohort in the total stand’s net photosynthetic assimilation of carbon is proportional to its share of the absorbed photosynthetically active radiation. The total fraction of photosynthetically active radiation absorbed by each tree cohort is calculated each time stand phenology changes, based on the Lambert-Beer law. Four models exist to calculate light transmission and absorption through the canopy.
fields.light_utilization: Light  use efficiency is calculated according to Haxeltine and Prentice (1996).
fields.phenology:
yes:
The phenological approach in 4C is based on the interaction of inhibitory and promotory agents that are assumed to control the developmental status of a plant.
The agents are driven by temperature and photoperiod, which play the most prominent role in phenology. Using these simple but basic principles a model for the
abundance or concentration of an inhibitory and a promotory compound made of a system of two difference equations is used (Schaber and Badeck, 2003).
fields.water_stress:
yes:
After calculating water demand by forest stand and water supply from the soil for each tree cohort photosynthesis is being reduced if demand is greater than supply. Allocation is also affected.
fields.evapotranspiration_approach:
yes:
Different approaches are used:
Turc/Ivanov, Priestley/Taylor, Penman/ Monteith.
fields.rooting_depth_differences:
yes: 
The model uses a fixed site-specific rooting depth as input parameter depending on soil characteristics.
fields.root_distribution:
yes
4C uses an approach according to Jackson (1996), which assumes an exponential decrease of fine root biomass with soil depth. Additionally, a site and species specific root distribution can be used as input.
fields.soil_moisture_surface_temperature_coupli:
yes:
4C includes  a coupled soil moisture and temperature model.
fields.mortality_age:
yes:
 The so called ‘age related’ mortality basing on life span corresponds to the intrinsic mortality developed by (Botkin, 1993).
fields.mortality_drought:
yes:

The response of trees to growth suppression by drought is described by a carbon-based stress mortality .
fields.mortality_insects:
yes:
Modelling of impacts of mistletoe, phloem feeder, defoliator, stem disturber, xylem disturber, root disturber is under construction.
fields.mortality_other: Self-thinning mortality due to light availability is implemented (stress mortality).
fields.nbp_harvest: The model includes harvests and all fluxes caused by thinning and harvesting (litter fall, harvest pool). Harvested biomass is pooled into different carbon pools and later on released to the atmosphere e.g. by decomposition.
fields.nbp_other: Dead biomass which is not harvested is an input to the litter pool, where it is decomposed.
fields.pfts_comments: 4C uses tree species and parameters for 13 tree species.

fields.spatial_scale: 30 Polygons covering ~270,000 sq. km, covering 60 years with 12 h r times steps and annual reporting
fields.taxonomic_scope: 50 groups, age structured vertebrates, 2 stages in inverts, covering phytoplankton to whales, inclusive of plankton, benthos and nekton, many aggregate groups with ~10 iconic spp modeled as spp
fields.vertical_resolution: Yes, 3-5 depth layers depending upon max depth in a box

fields.defining_features: Data rich, lots of calibration and prebal testing
fields.spatial_scale: 4 main boxes, all modeled separately, annual time steps
fields.taxonomic_scope: 30 groups, no age/stage structuring, ltd as spp but more functional groups, cover all TLs

fields.defining_features: fisheries for all comercial species included, mainly dominated by anchovy fisheries
